pros: Great people, growing rapidly, and very stable for a biotech startup. In part because it is consistently funded by its parent company in China
cons: Management is very conservative with funds on purchasing equipment and salaries

review_title: not the worst, but much room for improvement
years_at_company: not the worst, but much room for improvement
pros: you work with some great people and get a chance to do lots of different things
cons: leadership is out of touch with realistic expectations and constantly changing goals means slow net progress. pay for everyone but entry level is at the low end. non-salary benefits are well below industry standard.
advice_to_mgmt: let the experts do what they do best

review_title: Lack of direction and trust is discouraging.
years_at_company: Lack of direction and trust is discouraging.
pros:
-Excellent scientists and technicians with great experience and technical knowledge.
-Fairly good equipment and tech setup for such a small company.
cons:
-Upper management is inexperienced in the full process of biotech drug development and it shows. Constant requests/demands to shorten timelines and cut out developmental milestones, with no justification offered.
-Scientific integrity is becoming questionable, with senior management asking for "tests to prove X will do Y" instead of asking a question and seeing what results the tests produce.
-Little time is allowed for documentation, both in daily work and in writing larger reports and other supporting technical documents for transfer or later filings.
-Strange budgetary decisions - OK to buy a new mass spectrometer, but not OK to pay for a day's parking at the airport for an employee flying to a seminar and back in that one day.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to your scientists and trust them - you hired them in order to get the benefit of their years (or decades!) of experience, so utilize these resources. Explain why you want to cut timelines and throw out basic development, and how these risks will be handled moving forward.
